results.title: What's important to me?
results.creator_credit: Hamish Eden, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Hamish Eden is only thirteen, he is uncle to three nephews and a niece. He comes from a large family of twelve but Hamish shares the benefits of having so many brothers and sisters. They have been great rolemodels to Hamish and have taught him many different things, above all the importance of education.

results.title: What's happening to me?
results.creator_credit: Greg ingram, Steve Walsh, Stephen Smallwood and Consolidated Productions
results.brief_description: An honest, sympathetic and humorous animated presentation of the main changes occuring in females and males during puberty. Covers the growth of pubic and other body hair, menstruation, readiness for reproduction, growth of breasts, masturbation, erections, wet dreams, voice changes, pimples, different rates of onset of puberty and physical diferences between those of the same age and sex. Based on the book by Peter Mayle and Arthur Robins.

results.title: What's for lunch?
results.creator_credit: Jeff Spencer, David Ferris, Rob McCubbin, Trevor Lunn and Channel 7 for Curriculum Branch, Ministry of Education
results.brief_description: Panel discussion about nutrition in schools including scenes from actual classrooms, where panelists Phillip Hughes and Anne Keogh discuss a good food “Pyramid” with children at a Victorian primary school.

results.title: What's for dinner?
results.brief_description: This 3D animation tells the story of Angus and his overbearing mother Beryl. Eventually Angus must decide whether he wants to rid himself of Beryl forever…to be continued, Completed as part of a visual arts degree in graphic design

results.title: What's eating Gilbert Grape?
results.creator_credit: Lasse Hallstrom, David Matalon, Bertil Ohlsson, Meir Teper, J and M Entertainment and Matalon Teper Ohlsson Production
results.brief_description: From the acclaimed director of “My life as a dog”, “What’s eating Gilbert Grape?” is a moving and at times comic portrayal of an unusual family in a small town. Gilbert (Johnny Depp) must keep a vigilant eye on his family, particularly his intellectually disabled younger brother Arnie (Leonardo Di Caprio) and his reclusive mother. When a stranger (Juliette Lewis) comes to town, she not only captures his heart, but also turns his life around.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Lasse Hallstrom, David Matalon, Bertil Ohlsson, Meir Teper, J and M Entertainment and Matalon Teper Ohlsson Production

results.title: What's Cooking?
results.headline_credit: United Kingdom and United States of America, 2000
results.brief_description: In LA’s Fairfax district, where ethnic groups abound, four households celebrate Thanksgiving amidst family tensions.

constellations_other.name: Culture, food and family
constellations_other.description: Food as a link to culture and family.

results.headline_credit_for_label: United Kingdom and United States of America, 2000
results.description: In LA’s Fairfax district, where ethnic groups abound, four households celebrate Thanksgiving amidst family tensions. In the Nguyen family, the children’s acculturation and immigrant parents’ fears collide. In the Avila family, Isabel’s son has invited her estranged husband to their family dinner. Audrey and Ron Williams want to keep their own family’s ruptures secret from Ron’s visiting mother. In the Seelig household, Herb and Ruth are unwilling to discuss openly their grown daughter’s living with her lover, Carla. Around each table, things come to a head. A gun, an affair, a boyfriend, and a pregnancy precipitate crises forcing each family to find its center.
description_for_label: In LA’s Fairfax district, where ethnic groups abound, four households celebrate Thanksgiving amidst family tensions. In the Nguyen family, the children’s acculturation and immigrant parents’ fears collide. In the Avila family, Isabel’s son has invited her estranged husband to their family dinner. Audrey and Ron Williams want to keep their own family’s ruptures secret from Ron’s visiting mother. In the Seelig household, Herb and Ruth are unwilling to discuss openly their grown daughter’s living with her lover, Carla. Around each table, things come to a head. A gun, an affair, a boyfriend, and a pregnancy precipitate crises forcing each family to find its center.

results.title: What's cooking?
results.creator_credit: Gurinder Chadha, Jeffrey Taylor, Flashpoint Pictures and BeCause Entertainment
results.brief_description: Gurinda Chadha (Bend it like Beckham, Bhaji on the beach) directs this familial drama, set in Los Angeles that dissects the interplay between four clans gathered on Thanksgiving Day, a non-religious traditional day of feasting. In the Jewish Seeling family, Mum and Dad struggle to come to terms with their gay daughter, who has brought her girlfriend home for the holiday. Heading a traditional African-American family, Ronald works for a racist senator, whilst his visiting mother mercilessly criticises her daughter-in-law’s every move. Having fled Vietnam the Nguyens live in LA as an extended family, where the teenage children encounter difficulties with assimilation. Lastly, the Avila family celebrate their Latino roots, whilst feeling conflicted by the absence of their ostracised father. A common thread that runs through the film is tolerance and the difficulties inherent in accepting diversity - particularly in relation to the offspring’s choice of partners. Despite this interesting premise, Chadha cannot avoid entertaining a slew of cliches in order to fill the gaps dictated by such a large tapestry. This works against achieving a sense of realism - and many narrative threads wrap up tritely. Nevertheless the film retains a certain charm and it is refreshing to see Americans portrayed that are not white Anglo Saxon. There is the additional pleasure of watching the gastronomic diversity of numerous cultures on display. Cast includes: Dennis Haysbert, Julianna Margulies and Estelle Harris.

results.title: What's cooking?
results.creator_credit: Damian Brown, Don Anderson and Tasmanian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Presents a humorous look at the health problems which abound in the unhygienic kitchen and shows how to overcome these through following sanitary procedures. The film covers proper refridgeration of food, observation of shelf life of food products, how to recognise blown cans and the need to avoid using the same utensils for cooked and uncooked food. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: What's causing the problem? (Captioned)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Improving Performance”.
The second step in performance appraisal is the need to identify and agree on the cause of the work problem before discussing solutions. Examples of no agreement on cause are followed by Peter Quarry demonstrating clear agreement on cause.
